The 'Atlanta Braves' are a professional baseball team based in Atlanta, in the
U.S. state of Georgia. The Braves are a member of the Eastern Division of
Major League Baseball's National League. The Braves have played in Turner
Field since 1997. The teams has played its Spring Training games in Lake Buena
Vista, Florida.

The "Braves" name, which was first used in 1912, originates from a term for a
Native American warrior. They are nicknamed "the Bravos", and often referred to
as "America's Team" in reference to the team's games being broadcast on the
nationally available TBS from the 1970s until 2007, gaining a wide fanbase.

From 1991 to 2005 the Braves were one of the most successful franchises in
baseball, winning division titles an unprecedented 14 consecutive times in that
period [http://atlanta.braves.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20060-
913&content_id=1659755&vkey=news_atl&fext=.jsp&c_id=atl "Braves have set lofty
benchmark"], MLB.com, September 13, 2006 (omitting the strike-shortened
1994 season in which there were no official division champions). The Braves won
the NL West 1991â93 and the NL East 1995â2005, and returned to the playoffs as
the National League Wild Card in 2010. The Braves advanced to the World Series
five times in the 1990s, winning the title in 1995. Since their debut in the
National League in 1876, the franchise has won 16 divisional titles, 17 National
League pennants, as well as three World Series championshipsâin 1914 as the
Boston Braves, in 1957 as the Milwaukee Braves, and in 1995 in Atlanta. The
Braves are the only Major League Baseball franchise to have won the World Series
in three different home cities.

The club is one of the National League's two remaining charter franchises (the
other being the Chicago Cubs) and was founded in Boston, Massachusetts, in 1871
as the 'Boston Red Stockings' (not to be confused with the American League's
Boston Red Sox). They are considered "the oldest continuously playing team in
major North American sports." Millard, Mike.
[http://thephoenix.com/tools/print/?id=39678 Home of the Braves?] The Boston
Phoenix, May 9, 2007. There is an argument as to which team is actually
older, because, although the Cubs are a full season "older" (formed as the
Chicago White Stockings in 1870), Chicago did not sponsor a White Stockings team
for two seasons due to the Great Chicago Fire; therefore, the Braves have played
more consecutive seasons.

After various name changes, the team eventually began operating as the 'Boston
Braves', which lasted for most of the first half of the 20th century. Then, in
1953, the team moved to Milwaukee, Wisconsin and became the 'Milwaukee Braves',
followed by the final move to Atlanta in 1966. The team's tenure in Atlanta is
noted for Hank Aaron breaking Babe Ruth's career home run record in 1974.
categories: Professional baseball teams in Georgia (U.S. state)
